sentence: Salesforce.com (CRM) late Tuesday named Keith Block co-CEO, the latest promotion in his ascent to what many believe will be logical successor to company co-founder Marc Benioff.
The 57-year-old Block, who is Salesforce vice chairman, has been Chief Operating Officer since February 2016.
In his new role, Block will work alongside co-CEO Benioff, who remains chairman of the company he co-founded in 1999.
"Keith has been my trusted partner in running Salesforce for the past five years, and I'm thrilled to welcome him as co-CEO," Benioff said in a statement.
Salesforce shares are flat, at $145.10, in trading Wednesday.
Under Salesforce's new dual leadership, Benioff will oversee technology, marketing, stakeholder engagement, and culture; Block will spearhead growth strategy, execution, and operations.
Evercore ISI analysts deem the pairing a "winning combination" of Block's "operational and sales expertise" with Benioff's "technology vision" in reiterating an Outperform on the company.

"While we expect some investors will fret that this announcement is an indication that Mr. Benioff is looking to become less active in the business, we believe that is NOT the case and this is ultimately about having the right management structure for Salesforce to get to well beyond +$23bn in revenue and the best way to execute against its FY22 vision," the analysts wrote in a note Tuesday.
Block joined Salesforce in June 2013 from business-software rival Oracle (ORCL), and has helped lead rapid growth, expansion of the company's international presence, and partnerships.
The company has set $23 billion in revenue as its goal for fiscal year 2022.
The San Francisco-based company, with a market value of $106 billion, is among tech's better-performing stocks.
Its shares are up 41% this year, and 60% over the past 12 months.
